subject: doc: add a testing doc as guidelines for commits
commitMessage:
doc: add a testing doc as guidelines for commits

Context:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/50742 is a small
but important change that changes how http_connection works. Maintainers
recommends doing a more complete testing for this type of change. I
found that having some docs as reference when performing testing is
helpful for every contributor.

Add a document for different types of testing we want contributors to
perform and include results in their commit messages. This doc will
evolve.

Also moved relevant sections in existing docs into this doc.

Signed-off-by: Nan Zhou <nanzhoumails@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ia0b35950540ec6efaa813516d0e545c4b8f7c609

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 725525eaac83bb355fb34aec5513a0a499fb471c

While I love that you're writing documentation, and want to encourage it, can you please read through DEVELOPING.md and make sure none of it's duplicated?  For sure at the very least the redfish validator stuff is covered, which, if this documentation is better, I'm happy to have it superceed, but I don't want to maintain both.

Thanks Ed for the comment. 

I saw there is a "Developing and Testing
" and section in https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/DEVELOPING.md which has some duplicate information. 

Does moving that section into this dedicated doc for testing sound good to you? I will delete duplication after moving.
WDYT? I can modify this change to avoid duplication. But overall, getting some testing doc like this is helpful.
Sure, do what you think is best, with the idea that we don't duplicate information.  I'll review whatever you think we should do.
This section of doc of docs should really be in the robot framework documentation, not bmcweb.  They're not specific to bmcweb.
I can create a README in https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts, move these instructions there, and just make a link here in bmcweb's documentation. WDYT?

I'm not the openbmc-build-scripts maintainer, so that's a discussion to have this those guys.  I suspect they're going to recommend putting it somewhere else, (like the docs repo) but that's not my call.
I don't think the websocket test will give any results on a desktop/qemu setup, as there's no sensors?

Right, without signal triggered, it won't fetch sensors. It will at least test connection opening and closing.

I will mention it's recommended to use real hardware to get the best coverage.

The intent of that test is to push something that's reasonably chatty, and tests the full path.  I'd rather we just leave it undocumented than try to document something that doesn't actually test the full path.
Remove.  most of the world runs ssl by default.
With your patch, clang-tidy is now under the common errors heading, which I'm pretty sure wasn't your intent.
"## clang-tidy" is a separate section. It is a header level2. I thought it doesn't belong to "### Developing and Testing either", a level3 header, in the first place
Can we add a heading here for "environments"
This only needs to be a link.
I'm not sure what setting up gerrit has to do with testing.  Remove?

This second has really nothing to do with testing, and is not a workflow that I would like to maintain documentation of.  I realized that you just copied it from the old doc, and tes, it can be quite useful, but for testing purposes, I would like people to build within yocto and test the image as a whole, not just an scped copy of bmcweb.  Please remove this section.
Removed. Do you want to keep in the old Development doc? Or just completely remove?
Try to avoid personal acronyms "we" here.
No need to put in cross compilation.  That's implied by testing on a system.  Remove.

I'm not sure of the value this section provides to users.  Lets try rephrasing to something like:

A committer should run tests that exercise all paths changed in the patchset.  If making changes to the http core, that are expected to effect all types of routes, testing one route of each class (websocket, http get, http post) is required.
Remove.  This is not anything special about bmcweb, and is enforced by CI.  In general I don't expect committers to compile with every variation of build flags.  That's what CI is for.
This isn't an eg.....  dbus-rest is required to run this test, so you should call out to make sure it's enabled.
Oh, I might misunderstood it. Aren't there other websocket handlers?
Ack. Please open if I understood it wrong.
This section can be removed I think?  it's showing how to build a binary, but then suggesting to test on real hardware.
this isn't right if you're testing on a real bmc.

This needs stronger wording

"Commiters are required to run the service validator anytime they make a change to the GET behavior of the redfish tree"
Remove.  The service validator is fully capable of reporting errors.
please just fill these in with examples.

Please don't suggest this.  Something like:

Please include something to the effect of "Redfish service validator passing" in your commit message.
this isn't enough detail for this line item.

What do you need me to add here?

When I was testing these errors, I just hack the resource codes and return errors directly. Is that something you wanna me to add?
Ack. Let me know what else you need me to add here.

Looks fine to me.
Thanks for update the documentation

Thanks John!

Ed, any more comments?

In the future, when you're doing moves like this with either code or documentation, please put the move in one commit, and the changes you make to it in another.  This helps reviewers to see what you've actually changed in the old content, instead of just seeing a new block.  With that said, I'll let it slide this time.

Have you tried following these instructions?  The doc linked on line 22 is for doing a local build, not a cross compiled build, so I'm not quite understanding how these steps could work as written, maybe I'm missing something?

Also, as a general rule, if we're cross compiling for qemu, there's really not any good reason that I'm aware of to do it outside of yocto.  Generally SCPing a binary is done to avoid a BMC firmware update, which takes a while, but recompiling a qemu image is much faster, and doesn't require doing manual steps to cross compile.

I'm seeing that this was all copied from the other doc, so this is no worse, but as written it's definitely incorrect.
To be clear, I don't expect you to fix this in this patchset, just FYI that it's not very useful.
This is copied from the old block. Can be fixed in future PRs.

References a script that doesn't exist?

I would've expected this test to use https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Event-Listener

Lets remove the whole EventService section for the moment so we can get the majority of this patchset merged, and follow up in another patch that's adding event service testing.

I see this script was added in the next patchset.  Please organize your patchsets such that they're easy to review.  Ideally documentation for a new script should be done in the same commit, or its own commit next to the commit adding the functionality.
That's what I did in the first place. Somehow when doing rebase, the change in the next PR was moved to this one.
I just reviewed it friday, it's now monday, and I didn't look at patches over the weekend, so I'm getting to it.
Couple minor things, then this should be fine.
Thanks. We were talking about upstream commit testing guidelines in another internal thread. So I sent a ping here to bring it to your radar. Not ask you to work over weekends 😊
FWIW, I did work on sunday, but not because of this patch 😊
Probably don't need to mention IPMI in the redfish repo.
strange line wrapping?  Seems like those two didn't need a line break?
I don't necessarily agree with everything that already exists in our docs (there's lots of non-bmcweb specific stuff), but as an incremental improvement, this seems fine.
Is this commit good to go?
As always, happy to discuss, but this patch has been in review for several weeks, and is largely just moving around existing docs.
